title.narrative: Burkina Faso (le): Aide ciblée aux pays
Burkina Faso: Targeted country assistance

description.narrative:
L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

Cette activité détaille notre travail sur le Aide ciblée aux pays en Burkina Faso (le), grâce à la mise à disposition des données budgétaires et des transactions. Nous fournissons également les documents pertinents qui guident ces activités que sont les formulaires de demande de soutien fournis par le gouvernement de Burkina Faso (le) ainsi que les lettres de décisions émises par Gavi, pour progresser. Ces documents décrivent les activités, les objectifs ainsi que les bénéficiaires.

This activity details our work on Targeted country assistance in Burkina Faso through the provision of budget and transaction data. We also provide the relevant documents that guide these activities, which are the support request proposal(s) provided by the Government of Burkina Faso, as well as the decision letter(s) issued by Gavi, for progress. These documents describe the activities, the objectives as well as the beneficiaries.

title.narrative: CDC Foundation : Health Information Systems (Data)

Complete training of 4 national and >4 regional labs on detection of bacterial meningitis using the latest effective technology; Implement in-country programs to ensure lab proficiency. Complete analysis >90% of specimens collected between Jan-Aug 2020;

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under OneTA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for VPD program monitoring and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide technical support and trainings to strengthen the detection of bacterial meningitis pathogens; 2) reinforce quality control programs to ensure laboratory proficiency within the nation wide laboratory system; 3) Improve lab data management, analysis, and reporting practices.

title.narrative: Complete trainings on data management and analysis processes;Complete supervision visits to at least 5 sites; Complete analysis >90% of specimens collected in 2020

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under OneTA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for VPD program monitoring and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide technical support and trainings to strengthen the detection of bacterial meningitis pathogens; 2) reinforce quality control programs to ensure laboratory proficiency within the nation wide laboratory system; 3) Improve lab data management, analysis, and reporting practices.

In collaboration with Burkina Faso under OneTA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for VPD program monitoring and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide technical support and trainings to strengthen the detection of bacterial meningitis pathogens; 2) reinforce quality control programs to ensure laboratory proficiency within the nation wide laboratory system; 3) Improve lab data management, analysis, and reporting practices.

title.narrative: Consistent weekly reporting of meningitis cases and testing of CSF obtained from participating districts; generation of weekly meningitis surveillance bulletins/reports for MOH and key partners to monitor trends in meningitis disease and early detection of epidemics.

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under a One TA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for multi-disease VPD program monitoring, early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide epidemiological support and tools to ensure efficient data/specimen collection, management, and country-level analysis to accurately assess the burden of bacterial meningitis in the context of vaccine implementation and integration into broader health information systems (i..e DHIS2); 2) integrate with other national disease priorities to ensure data triangulation between immunization and disease surveillance; 3) reinforce the country's capacity for epidemic detection and response. Efforts will be harmonized and coordinated with other regional/global activities and partners (i.e. MenAfriNet, WHO ICG Vaccine Stockpile)

In collaboration with Burkina Faso under a One TA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for multi-disease VPD program monitoring, early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide epidemiological support and tools to ensure efficient data/specimen collection, management, and country-level analysis to accurately assess the burden of bacterial meningitis in the context of vaccine implementation and integration into broader health information systems (i..e DHIS2); 2) integrate with other national disease priorities to ensure data triangulation between immunization and disease surveillance; 3) reinforce the country's capacity for epidemic detection and response. Efforts will be harmonized and coordinated with other regional/global activities and partners (i.e. MenAfriNet, WHO ICG Vaccine Stockpile)

title.narrative: Support lab testing at 4 national and 5 regional labs that have been trained for the detection and characterization of bacterial meningitis and specimen referral;

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under OneTA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to strengthen laboratory systems for vaccine preventable diseases surveillance including epidemic prone meningitis disease, and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) Continue to support laboratory based surveillance for rapid/timely detection and characterization of bacterial meningitis pathogens at national and regional levels; 2) strengthen nation-wide lab network through reinforcing proper specimen management and lab testing flows; 3) implement effective measures to improve laboratory quality, proficiency and data quality. 4) provide technical support for preparation and participation of annual meningitis meetings and other meetings

title.narrative: Evaluation of data management and specimen transport system efficiency and integration status

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under a One TA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for multi-disease VPD program monitoring and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide epidemiological support and tools to ensure efficient data/specimen collection, management, and country-level analysis to accurately assess the burden of bacterial meningitis in the context of vaccine implementation and integration into broader health information systems (i..e DHIS2); 2) integrate with other national disease priorities to ensure data triangulation between immunization and disease surveillance; 3) reinforce the country's capacity for epidemic detection and response. Efforts will be harmonized and coordinated with other regional/global activities and partners (i.e. MenAfriNet, WHO ICG Vaccine Stockpile), 4) technical support for preparation and participation in Annual Meeting of Meningitis Belt Countries

title.narrative: Generation of routine meningitis surveillance performance feedback summaries to guide national monitoring and evaluation, with a target of >90% of participating districts reporting data monthly and >80 of suspected meningitis cases have a specimen collected

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under a One TA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to leverage and strengthen case-based surveillance for multi-disease VPD program monitoring and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) provide epidemiological support and tools to ensure efficient data/specimen collection, management, and country-level analysis to accurately assess the burden of bacterial meningitis in the context of vaccine implementation and integration into broader health information systems (i..e DHIS2); 2) integrate with other national disease priorities to ensure data triangulation between immunization and disease surveillance; 3) reinforce the country's capacity for epidemic detection and response. Efforts will be harmonized and coordinated with other regional/global activities and partners (i.e. MenAfriNet, WHO ICG Vaccine Stockpile), 4) technical support for preparation and participation in Annual Meeting of Meningitis Belt Countries

title.narrative: Evaluate specimen management and lab testing flows for meningitis within national laboratory network; Develop a standardized program to ensure lab quality and proficiency

target.value: In collaboration with Burkina Faso under OneTA plan, CDC/DBD proposes the following activities to strengthen laboratory systems for vaccine preventable diseases surveillance including epidemic prone meningitis disease, and early detection of disease epidemics to guide equitable deployment of emergency meningococcal stockpile vaccines: 1) Continue to support laboratory based surveillance for rapid/timely detection and characterization of bacterial meningitis pathogens at national and regional levels; 2) strengthen nation-wide lab network through reinforcing proper specimen management and lab testing flows; 3) implement effective measures to improve laboratory quality, proficiency and data quality. 4) provide technical support for preparation and participation of annual meningitis meetings and other meetings

title.narrative: World Bank : Health Financing/Sustainability
Delivery of the training modules and the programmatic budget advances with Finance.

target.value: TCA 2019 was the first year of engagement of the GAVI-WBG partnership in Burkina Faso. Following the January 2019 joint mission conclusions, the team is preparing elements for a public expenditure review, with an initial focus on the budget cycle and gratuité. These were to be delivered for the December UHC Financing Forum, which is likely to be moved to the first quarter of 2020. Additional notes are planned, including one to support prospective evaluation of budget allocation, and will be discussed with donors and the ministry. The results will feed into the forum discussion on efficiency of public spending and will support better budgeting in 2020 by the ministry and its partners through a revision of the budgeting approach to focus on priority results. The 2020 TCA will involve two parts that will be mutually-reinforcing. Centrally, the team will support the Ministry of Health with the Ministry of Finance on programmatic budgeting including questions of budgetary flexibility and implementation of prospective budget reviews to support the ministry in dealing with budget cuts and to better align the budget to the MoH objectives. This will complement planned work by CHAI and a USAID contractor. The team will also work with the Ministries of Health and Finance to develop new modules on programmatic and priority-based budgeting for the annual training of district medical officers. This training is supported by the WB-financed PRSS operation and all future ministry management staff go through this training program. Therefore, the training will has the potential to have downstream impacts beyond the initial training. There is the potential to also provide support to the Ministry of Health to better allocate human resources with the newly-developed human resource database and the Workload Indicative Staffing Needs information. This is closely linked to the ongoing Development Policy Financing?s measure to strengthen human resources in rural areas. The team has identified as an additional possible reform measure that requires technical assistance to develop tools to help ministry staff to better understand their human and material resources to adjust allocations.

TCA 2019 was the first year of engagement of the GAVI-WBG partnership in Burkina Faso. Following the January 2019 joint mission conclusions, the team is preparing elements for a public expenditure review, with an initial focus on the budget cycle and gratuité. These were to be delivered for the December UHC Financing Forum, which is likely to be moved to the first quarter of 2020. Additional notes are planned, including one to support prospective evaluation of budget allocation, and will be discussed with donors and the ministry. The results will feed into the forum discussion on efficiency of public spending and will support better budgeting in 2020 by the ministry and its partners through a revision of the budgeting approach to focus on priority results.
The 2020 TCA will involve two parts that will be mutually-reinforcing. Centrally, the team will support the Ministry of Health with the Ministry of Finance on programmatic budgeting including questions of budgetary flexibility and implementation of prospective budget reviews to support the ministry in dealing with budget cuts and to better align the budget to the MoH objectives. This will complement planned work by CHAI and a USAID contractor. The team will also work with the Ministries of Health and Finance to develop new modules on programmatic and priority-based budgeting for the annual training of district medical officers. This training is supported by the WB-financed PRSS operation and all future ministry management staff go through this training program. Therefore, the training will has the potential to have downstream impacts beyond the initial training.
There is the potential to also provide support to the Ministry of Health to better allocate human resources with the newly-developed human resource database and the Workload Indicative Staffing Needs information. This is closely linked to the ongoing Development Policy Financing?s measure to strengthen human resources in rural areas. The team has identified as an additional possible reform measure that requires technical assistance to develop tools to help ministry staff to better understand their human and material resources to adjust allocations.

TCA 2019 was the first year of engagement of the GAVI-WBG partnership in Burkina Faso. Following the January 2019 joint mission conclusions, the team is preparing elements for a public expenditure review, with an initial focus on the budget cycle and gratuité. These were to be delivered for the December UHC Financing Forum, which is likely to be moved to the first quarter of 2020. Additional notes are planned, including one to support prospective evaluation of budget allocation, and will be discussed with donors and the ministry. The results will feed into the forum discussion on efficiency of public spending and will support better budgeting in 2020 by the ministry and its partners through a revision of the budgeting approach to focus on priority results.
The 2020 TCA will involve two parts that will be mutually-reinforcing. Centrally, the team will support the Ministry of Health with the Ministry of Finance on programmatic budgeting including questions of budgetary flexibility and implementation of prospective budget reviews to support the ministry in dealing with budget cuts and to better align the budget to the MoH objectives. This will complement planned work by CHAI and a USAID contractor. The team will also work with the Ministries of Health and Finance to develop new modules on programmatic and priority-based budgeting for the annual training of district medical officers. This training is supported by the WB-financed PRSS operation and all future ministry management staff go through this training program. Therefore, the training will has the potential to have downstream impacts beyond the initial training.
There is the potential to also provide support to the Ministry of Health to better allocate human resources with the newly-developed human resource database and the Workload Indicative Staffing Needs information. This is closely linked to the ongoing Development Policy Financing?s measure to strengthen human resources in rural areas. The team has identified as an additional possible reform measure that requires technical assistance to develop tools to help ministry staff to better understand their human and material resources to adjust allocations.
